description: The wifi wasn't working and the guy at the counter couldn't have been more rude about it. I expect better customer service when I'm paying that much for coffee.
author: Carolyn S.

description: Ambling down Columbus I tried to get into Brioche for lunch but it was SRO and long line; so checked out the new next door "RCC" or Reveille. Terrific brisket sandwich on crusty baguette with soft, gravy-soaked interior, whiffs of wasabi /horseradish, arugula, caramelized onion and black pepper. A nice tang but not a hint of jalapeño. And on the side, more of the arugula, with radish slices and a little tub of lemony vinaigrette. Four Barrel coffee, nice personnel, fast service and a clean contemporary interior with acres of windows to watch the Columbus action complete a favorable first impression. Will be back to try the bkfst offerings.
author: Leigh G.

description: Amazing coffee - love their cappuccinos. They have food too. I'm determined to become a regular.
author: Krista P.

description: Réveille brings your idea of what a San Francisco coffee shop ought to be to life. It's beautifully designed with the central area reserved for making various delicious and potent blends from around the world. The tables along the sides, flooded with natural light from the big windows, make Réveille a great place to meet or just sit and think. The guys working there are all nice and accommodating and the food is fresh, healthy and tasty to boot.
author: Ryan S.

description: Feeling generous so leaving 2 stars.  Coffee-5 stars.  Service is pretty good-4 or 5.  But please do not order your lunch or snacks here.  I ordered a PB&J, thinking it would be a sandwich.  I realize the name said toast on the menu, but I didn't realize that I was going to pay $4.5 for literally a piece of toast with some sad PB&J slathered on top.  Never again.  I think I'll stick to the truck for my coffee needs only.
author: Nancy C.

description: Great coffee. Cool cafe. Staff is always very friendly. On par with all the other new wave SF coffee shops, but maybe slightly less hipster.
author: W W.

description: Great neighborhood spot in north beach/chinatown. They have a short menu but everything I've had has been great. Good coffee you can get anywhere so go here for the egg sandwich with bacon. It's got an egg in a basket for half the sandwich and the other side is sauteed kale with gruyere cheese and bacon. Add avocado because you should always add it when given the opportunity. Pb&j toast is solid too and not offered at enough places IMHO.
author: Robert K.

description: Cute modern place. I don't know what was here before, but it's a nice addition. Their coffees are really good. Had a cafe latte and the milk was soo creamy and frothy!
author: Natalie S.

description: My new favorite coffee shop in SF! The coffee is amazing, and the food is so delicious! They have great lunch options, and really yummy baked goods. A definite must!
author: Meg B.

description:
It would be forgivable if you assumed that this was another overpriced, slow, and pretentious hipster coffee shop at first glance. I'm guilty of that first gleaning.

However, this has become one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. The coffee is really good, fairly priced, and the staff is always impossibly nice. On top of all that, before I can tell them how my weekend went, my coffee is already on the counter.

If you're in the mood for a fancypants drink, get the dirty chai on ice.
author: Chris G.

description: This is a great spot to grab a coffee and light breakfast. The drip coffee's are amazing and the the egg-in-a-hole and yogurt-n-granola make for a perfect snack to go along with the coffee. it's not a great place to bring a laptop and work for a couple hours due to the type of seating they have  but it's perfect for a quick coffee and some great people watching out the large windows onto busy Columbus street in North Beach.  I'll definitely continue going there.
author: Jamie G.

description: Amazing Coffee, quick service, and pastries from starter bakery. Fuck Yeah!
author: Max R.

description: The cafe latte are always presented in a delightfully artistic manner. The flavor is no less impressive.  Smooth, creamy texture and rich flavor makes it one of the best cafe latte in town! Definitely worth coming back for...
author: S T.

description: Great coffee from 4 barrel. Modern interior design, well designed for the triangular corner shape of the space. Not too many tables, most of the seating is at the benches along the windows. I'd come here often if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: David K.

description: Awesome coffee, amazing breakfast egg sandwich and super nice guys running the place.
author: Gilad G.

description: Four Barrel Coffee---my favorite. Great location and minimalist decor. Still working out a few kinks, but happy they're here.
author: Paul K.

description: i love the coffee. no complaining. i have only had their coffee from their truck. haven't had a chance to stop by the brick & mortar shop but i am sure i won't be displeased. it's awesome that you guys are keeping up momentum and have a storefront!
author: Donald G.

description: Been working from the neighborhood for about six months, and I've always been let down by the morning coffee experience (Happy Doughnut was a warm, greasy welcome).  I went to Réveille Coffee after it opened, and it has been a godsend.  A nice, friendly staff serving pour-over or drip coffee and delicious egg and kale sandwiches (which tastes better than it sounds).  It has instantly become my new go-to coffee shop in North Beach.
author: Geoff H.

description:
Good Coffee and very unique touch of artistry on the breakfast food. .  My take
- Artisan sandwiches , with nice touch of coffee will make your day.
- Bit pricey but you pay for the location, presentation of the food.
- Like the ambiance.
author: Rajesh S.

description: No wi-fi. Seriously? That was frustrating since I had already ordered breakfast and wanted to do some work while I had my coffee. And all their food is super overpriced. Not a bad place if you just come to grab a coffee to go.
author: Maddy D.

description:
Best latte in SF. 

Very nice shop, modern but comfortable.
author: Matt F.

description: Best / most unique Saturday brunch menu I've experienced in a long time. The coffee is killer. This place is a must go!
author: Scott S.

description: I like how they don't use blue bottle and provide some different choices for cafe goers around the area. I however am not a big fan of the space, it's a great space if you like to look out into the room, I personally prefer space where I can see the people inside the room. When compare with station SF, I will def say I prefer station SF that's right across the street. I had the Rwanda drip, it tastes OK. Nothing spectacular about it thou. And at the particular afternoon when I was at this cafe, the cafe is filled with annoying heavy metal music, it might have been appealing for another, but for me, that was enough to warrant me not coming back here.
author: Fung S. O.

description: The coffee is good and the location is great. However major attitude and a hipster scene. I don't need the pretentiousness- just wanted a great cup of coffee. I found The Station across the street to be way more relaxed and friendlier. They also serve Blue Bottle. I would go there instead.
author: Laurene R.

description: Best almond milk capp. And their pour-overs are usually very good, too. Nice interior, great parklet for seating outside.
author: Esther L.

description: Had a soy vanilla late,  very good despite not being the biggest fan of vanilla late(more of a Carmel late person) it was surprisingly good. Excellent late art also.
author: Peter G.

description: Love this delicious coffee.  Perfect temp.   Smooth.   Now I don't have to drive down to Hayes Valley for Blue Bottle!
author: Lee M.

description:
pretty huge fail. 

i stopped by last week, ordered 2 sandwiches for my husband and me: the brisket ($12) and the turkey ($11). we shared the brisket first. it tasted ok, but it was TINY. like, doll-size. this might have been acceptable had the filling been generous, but it was not. (now, Little Vine's sandwiches are spendy but at least you get good value for the price.)

then, the turkey. a bite in, and both of us were, "wtf?" not turkey. it was some kind of fish thing, which we would have never ordered. turns out it was "fish conserva," which, according to the menu posted at the store, included swordfish, olives, capers, and red onions. my husband felt sick from eating it. i ate mine, only because i was starving, and only because it didn't, thank christ, have the advertised red onions in it. (i guess they thought red peppers were close enough.)

here's the thing: when i'm paying $12 for a sandwich, i want it to be of value, either in terms of size or contents. and i want it to be presented as advertised. and finally, i want it to be the freakin' item i *ordered*. fail x 3. (and no, it was not possible for me to trek back to the cafe and say, ps: you gave me the wrong food. also, i know people make mistakes but the cafe was pretty empty so it's not like they were slammed with customers.)

also: the sandwiches came with a choice of a side. i ordered the farro and quinoa salads. the farro was bland, even though it came with some of my favorite ingredients (brussels sprouts and pumpkin seeds). there was also supposed to be yogurt in it, but good luck finding that. on the other hand, the quinoa salad, which  included persimmons and pine nuts, was fantastic. supposedly there was goat cheese in the dressing. couldn't tell, but perhaps that's what made it so delicious. unfortunately, portion size was again lame. the salad came in one of those small plastic containers that you get at the deli counter at whole foods, only it was half-filled. seriously chintzy.

on the plus side, the people who work there were very nice, and it's a beautiful space. but overall, a real disappointment, and at $23, a rip-off. i'd rather go to Station SF, where the food and coffee is fantastic and a much better value.
author: m r.

description: Best coffee in town.  I was a regular at their coffee truck since it first opened and am thrilled that they've also started a coffee shop.  Great location and beautiful space.
author: Anne D.

description: These guys are awesome, their coffee is good. They have treats for local dogs. Soymilk available. No IV service yet but when they come up with that I'll sign up.
author: Erika L.

description: Nice, clean and friendly place. Staffs really relaxed, coffee is always great. Three outside bistro tables on the east so you can sit in the sun in the morning and enjoy your breakfast. Bacon egg and cheese sandwich comes with kale which was great.
author: Harry F.

description: finally a small coffee joint with excellent coffee and no condescending hipster attitude!
author: Pan P.

description: this people look like they are all new employees
author: John M.
